summary: This is a Department of Justice press release announcing the release of the Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) executive summary report on the 2006-2008 federal investigation of Jeffrey Epstein. The report found that while DOJ attorneys did not engage in professional misconduct, the victims were not treated with proper sensitivity, and former U.S. Attorney Acosta exercised poor judgment in handling the case and the non-prosecution agreement.

events.title: Release of OPR Report Executive Summary
events.description: The Department of Justice's Office of Professional Responsibility released the executive summary of its report on the handling of the Epstein investigation to affected victims and made it available on its website.

keyFacts: The DOJ's Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) investigated the handling of the 2006-2008 federal criminal investigation of Jeffrey Epstein by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida.
OPR did not find that Department attorneys engaged in professional misconduct.
OPR concluded that the victims of Epstein's crimes were not treated with the 'forthrightness and sensitivity expected by the Department.'
OPR concluded that former U.S. Attorney Acosta exercised poor judgment by resolving the federal investigation through a non-prosecution agreement with Epstein.
OPR also concluded Acosta failed to ensure the state of Florida would notify victims identified through the federal investigation about the state plea hearing.
